Petraeus is placed in command of the war in Afghanistan and Paula Broadwell begins making several trips to visit and observe him in the field.
Their relationship remains strictly professional at this time.
Petraeus is sworn in as CIA director with his wife, Holly, by his side.
Broadwell keeps in contact with Petraeus and is later invited to his office for events, including a meeting with actress Angelina Jolie.
Broadwell's book about Petraeus, 'All In: The Education of David Petraeus,' is published, and she appears on the Daily Show with Jon Stewart to promote it.
Jill Kelley tells an FBI agent, who is a personal friend, that she has been receiving harassing or threatening emails from Paula Broadwell.
The FBI begins an investigation into the emails.
House Majority Leader Eric Cantor's office gets a call from an unnamed FBI source, notifying him of Petraeus' affair.
Cantor's office calls the FBI chief of staff, saying it heard from an FBI whistleblower who raised concerns that the Petraeus matter was being covered up or not being taken seriously.
The FBI interviews Paula Broadwell for the second time.
The interview, along with another with Petraeus, allows the FBI to formally conclude there was no basis for criminal charges in the matter.
Director of National Intelligence James Clapper is informed of the FBI investigation and the Petraeus-Broadwell affair.
Petraeus submits his resignation to President Obama.
President Obama accepts Petraeus' resignation.
Jill Kelley is named as the woman who received the emails from Paula Broadwell.
Defense Secretary Leon Panetta announces the Pentagon has begun an internal investigation into emails between Gen. John Allen, the top U.S. commander in Afghanistan, and Jill Kelley.
The FBI and Justice Department are notified by their agents that the investigation into the threatening emails led them to evidence of an extramarital affair between Petraeus and Broadwell.
President Obama states at a press conference that there is no evidence classified information was compromised in the Petraeus matter.
The CIA launches an investigation into whether Petraeus used any agency resources to carry out his affair with Paula Broadwell.
Petraeus also testifies on Capitol Hill about what the CIA knew regarding the Sept. 11 attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya.
A Defense Department inspector general investigation into allegations of professional misconduct clears Gen. John Allen of wrongdoing.
